questions.question: What was the total amount of goodwill recorded by Lockheed Martin as a result of its acquisition of Terran Orbital, and how much of the purchase consideration was paid in cash?
questions.answer: Lockheed Martin recorded $298 million in goodwill as a result of the acquisition of Terran Orbital, and $231 million of the total $314 million purchase consideration was paid in cash.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The acquisition of Terran Orbital was completed for a total purchase consideration of $314 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - $231 million of the purchase price was paid in cash, and $298 million in goodwill was recorded at the Space business segment.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Lockheed Martin Corporation

## Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

## Note 1 - Organization and Significant Accounting Policies

Organization -  We  are  a  global  aerospace  and  defense  company  principally  engaged  in  the  research,  design,  development,  manufacture,  integration  and sustainment of advanced technology systems, products and services. We also provide a broad range of management, engineering, technical, scientific, logistics, system integration and cybersecurity services. We serve both U.S. and international customers with products and services that have defense, civil and commercial applications, with our principal customers being agencies of the U.S. G overnment. As described in 'Note 3 - Information on Business Segments', we operate in four business segments: Aeronautics, MFC, RMS and Space.

Basis of presentation -  These consolidated financial statements include the accounts of subsidiaries we control and variable interest entities if we are the primary beneficiary. We eliminate intercompany balances and transactions in consolidation. We classify certain assets and liabilities as current utilizing the duration of the related contract or program as our operating cycle, which is generally longer than one year. This primarily impacts receivables, contract assets, inventories, and contract liabilities. We classify all other assets and liabilities based on whether the asset will be realized or the liability will be paid within one year. Additionally, certain  prior  year  amounts  in  the  consolidated  statements  of  cash  flows  have  been  reclassified  within  operating  activities  to  conform  to  the  current  year's presentation. These reclassifications were not material and had no impact on total net cash provided by operating activities as previously reported.

On October 30, 2024, we closed our acquisition of Terran Orbital Corporation (Terran Orbital) for a purchase consideration of $314 million. We accounted for this acquisition as a 'step acquisition' (as defined in U.S. GAAP) and accordingly, $83 million of our previously held investments in Terran Orbital were included as part of the purchase consideration. The remaining purchase price of $231 million was paid with cash on hand (net of cash acquired). Terran Orbital became a whollyowned subsidiary and operates within our Space business segment. The purchase consideration of $314 million was allocated to the estimated fair value of net tangible and intangible assets acquired, with any excess purchase price recorded as goodwill. As a result, we recorded goodwill of $298 million at our Space business segment. The final determination of the fair values of certain assets and liabilities will be completed within the measurement period of up to one year from the respective acquisition date. The financial results of Terran Orbital have been included within our operating results in the period post-acquisition.

Use of estimates - We prepare our consolidated financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP). In doing so, we are required to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. We base these estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Our actual results may differ materially from these estimates. Significant estimates inherent in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements include, but are not limited to, accounting for sales and cost recognition; postretirement benefit plans; environmental liabilities and assets for the portion of environmental costs that are probable of future recovery; evaluation of  goodwill,  intangible  assets,  investments  and  other  assets  for  impairment;  income  tax es  including  deferred  income  tax es;  fair  value  measurements;  and contingencies.

Revenue Recognition -The majority of our net sales are generated from long-term contracts with the U.S. G overnment and international customers (including foreign military sales (FMS) contracted through the U.S. G overnment) for the research, design, development, manufacture, integration and sustainment of advanced technology systems, products and services. We account for a contract when it has approval and commitment from both parties, the rights of the parties are identified, payment terms are identified, the contract has commercial substance and collectability of consideration is probable. For certain contracts that meet the foregoing requirements, primarily international direct commercial sale contracts, we are required to obtain certain regulatory approvals. In these cases, we recognize revenue when it is probable that we will receive regulatory approvals based upon all known facts and circumstances. We provide our products and services under fixed-price and cost-reimbursable contracts.

Under fixed-price contracts, we agree to perform the specified work for a pre-determined price. To the extent our actual costs vary from the estimates upon which the price was negotiated, we will generate more or less profit or could incur a loss. Some fix ed-price contracts have a performance-based component under which we may earn incentive payments or incur financial penalties based on our performance.

Cost-reimbursable contracts provide for the payment of allowable costs incurred during performance of the contract plus a fee up to a ceiling based on the amount that has been funded. Typically, we enter into three types of cost-reimbursable contracts: cost-plus-award-fee, cost-plus-incentive-fee, and cost-plus-fixedfee. Cost-plus-award-fee contracts provide for an

questions.question: What is the total projected funding requirement for Lockheed Martin's qualified defined benefit pension plans over the next decade, and how does the pattern of annual increases from 2025 to 2029 inform the trend in pension obligations?
questions.answer: The total projected funding requirement for Lockheed Martin's qualified defined benefit pension plans over the next decade is $19,510 million. This includes $1,800 million in 2025, increasing to $1,860 million in 2026, $1,910 million in 2027, $1,960 million in 2028, $1,990 million in 2029, and $9,990 million from 2030 to 2034. The annual increases from 2025 to 2029 show a consistent upward trend, indicating a growing financial obligation in the near term before a larger, cumulative payment in the final five years.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract the specific projected funding amounts for qualified defined benefit pension plans from 2025 to 2029 and 2030–2034 from the data provided in the evidence chunk.
Step 2: Sum the annual amounts to determine the total funding requirement over the next decade: $1,800 + $1,860 + $1,910 + $1,960 + $1,990 + $9,990 = $19,510 million.
Step 3: Analyze the pattern of increases from 2025 to 2029, which rise incrementally each year, suggesting a steady growth in pension obligations before the larger cumulative payment phase.

questions.question: What was the total combined value of Mortgage/Asset-backed securities held by Honeywell in both 2020 and 2021, and how did this investment category rank in terms of proportion to total fixed income investments in each year?
questions.answer: The total combined value of Mortgage/Asset-backed securities held by Honeywell in 2020 and 2021 was $1,072 million + $982 million = $2,054 million. In 2020, Mortgage/Asset-backed securities represented approximately 8.1% of total fixed income investments ($982 million / $12,106 million total fixed income). In 2021, this category represented approximately 8.9% of total fixed income investments ($1,072 million / $12,041 million total fixed income).
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The value of Mortgage/Asset-backed securities in 2020 was $982 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The value of Mortgage/Asset-backed securities in 2021 was $1,072 million.
Step 3: Calculate the total combined value: $982 million + $1,072 million = $2,054 million.

Step 4: Extract total fixed income investments from evidence_source_a - $12,106 million (sum of Short term investments, Government securities, Corporate bonds, Mortgage/Asset-backed securities, and Insurance contracts in 2020: $1,314M + $1,520M + $10,190M + $982M + $7M).

Step 5: Extract total fixed income investments from evidence_source_b - $12,041 million (sum of Short term investments, Government securities, Corporate bonds, Mortgage/Asset-backed securities, and Insurance contracts in 2021: $1,767M + $1,373M + $9,588M + $1,072M + $8M).
Step 6: Calculate the proportion of Mortgage/Asset-backed securities in total fixed income for both years: 2020 = $982M / $12,106M ≈ 8.1%, 2021 = $1,072M / $12,041M ≈ 8.9%.
Step 7: Synthesize - The investment in Mortgage/Asset-backed securities slightly increased in value from 2020 to 2021 and also increased slightly in proportion to total fixed income investments.

questions.question: What was the total value of Insurance buy-in contracts held by HON in Non-U.S. Plans across 2020 and 2021, and what percentage of the total assets at fair value did this combined amount represent?
questions.answer: The total value of Insurance buy-in contracts held by HON in Non-U.S. Plans across 2020 and 2021 was $1,458 million ($767 million in 2020 + $691 million in 2021). This represented approximately 8.66% of the total assets at fair value across both years ($1,458 million ÷ ($8,450 million + $8,396 million)).
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the value of Insurance buy-in contracts for 2020: $767 million.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the value of Insurance buy-in contracts for 2021: $691 million.
Step 3: From evidence_source_a, extract total assets at fair value for 2020: $8,450 million.
Step 4: From evidence_source_b, extract total assets at fair value for 2021: $8,396 million.
Step 5: Calculate the combined value of Insurance buy-in contracts: $767 million + $691 million = $1,458 million.
Step 6: Calculate the combined total assets at fair value: $8,450 million + $8,396 million = $16,846 million.
Step 7: Calculate the percentage representation: ($1,458 million ÷ $16,846 million) × 100 = 8.66%.

questions.question: What specific actuarial assumption became inapplicable as a result of the freeze on U.S. pension benefits, and where is further information about the accounting for postretirement benefits disclosed?
questions.answer: The specific actuarial assumption that became inapplicable as a result of the freeze on U.S. pension benefits is the 'expected rate of compensation increase assumption'. Further information about the accounting for postretirement benefits is disclosed in Note 12 - 'Postemployment benefit plans' of Part II, Item 8 'Financial Statement and Supplemental Data'.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, we learn that as of December 31, 2019, all U.S. pension benefits were frozen, making the 'expected rate of compensation increase assumption' no longer applicable.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, we confirm the same pension freeze date and are directed to Note 12 in the financial statements for further details on postretirement benefits accounting.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
Effective	December	31,	2019,	all	U.S.	pension	benefits	were	frozen,	and	accordingly	the	expected	rate	of	compensation	increase	assumption	is	no longer	applicable. 1

## Actuarial	Assumptions

questions.question: How does Caterpillar's use of historical claim rates in determining product warranty liabilities influence its financial obligations related to dealer loans guaranteed through the special-purpose corporation, and what would be the impact on Caterpillar's financial position if a 10% non-temporary decrease in the market value of equipment on operating leases occurred alongside an increase in warranty claims?
questions.answer: Caterpillar uses historical claim rates to estimate future warranty costs, which directly affects its product warranty liability. This liability is updated monthly based on actual claim experience, and it ensures that Caterpillar can account for potential financial obligations tied to product warranties at the time of sale. Simultaneously, Caterpillar's financial services arm, Cat Financial, guarantees loans made by a special-purpose corporation (SPC) to Caterpillar dealers. If dealers face financial distress—potentially due to broader market conditions such as lower equipment values—they may default on these loans, triggering Caterpillar's obligation under the guarantee. A 10% non-temporary decrease in the market value of equipment on operating leases would result in approximately $75 million of additional annual depreciation expense. If this depreciation increase occurred alongside higher-than-expected warranty claims, Caterpillar would face dual financial pressures: higher operating expenses from depreciation and potentially higher warranty liabilities, which could strain cash flow and profitability.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Caterpillar determines product warranty liability by applying historical claim rate experience to the current field population and dealer inventory, with updates based on actual warranty experience.

Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Cat Financial guarantees dealer loans through an SPC, and is the primary beneficiary, consolidating the SPC's financials. If dealers face financial stress, Cat Financial may be obligated to perform under the guarantee.

Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_a - A 10% non-temporary decrease in the market value of equipment on operating leases would result in approximately $75 million of additional annual depreciation expense.

Step 4: Synthesize - If the $75 million depreciation increase coincides with higher warranty claims (due to increased product returns or defects), Caterpillar would face higher operating costs and increased liabilities, which could negatively affect profitability and cash flow.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

Upon	termination	of	the	lease,	the	equipment	is	either	purchased	by	the	lessee	or	sold	to	a	third-party,	in	which	case	we	may record	a	gain	or	a	loss	for	the	difference	between	the	estimated	residual	value	and	the	sale	proceeds.

During	 the	 term	 of	 our	 leases,	 we	 monitor	 residual	 values.	 	 For	 operating	 leases,	 we	 record	 adjustments	 to	 depreciation expense	 reflecting	 changes	 in	 residual	 value	 estimates	 prospectively	 on	 a	 straight-line	 basis.	 For	 finance	 leases,	 we recognize	residual	value	adjustments	through	a	reduction	of	finance	revenue	over	the	remaining	lease	term.

We	evaluate	the	carrying	value	of	equipment	on	operating	leases	for	potential	impairment	when	we	determine	a	triggering	event has	occurred.	When	a	triggering	event	occurs,	we	perform	a	test	for	recoverability	by	comparing	projected	undiscounted	future cash	flows	to	the	carrying	value	of	the	equipment	on	operating	leases.	If	the	test	for	recoverability	identifies	a	possible impairment,	we	measure	the	fair	value	of	the	equipment	on	operating	leases	in	accordance	with	the	fair	value	measurement framework.	We	recognize	an	impairment	charge	for	the	amount	by	which	the	carrying	value	of	the	equipment	on	operating	leases exceeds	its	estimated	fair	value.

At	December	31,	2023,	the	aggregate	residual	value	of	equipment	on	operating	leases	was	$1.70	billion.	Without	consideration of	other	factors	such	as	third-party	residual	guarantees	or	contractual	customer	purchase	options,	a	10	percent	non-temporary decrease	in	the	market	value	of	our	equipment	subject	to	operating	leases	would	reduce	residual	value	estimates	and	result	in the	recognition	of	approximately	$75	million	of	additional	annual	depreciation	expense.

Fair	 values	 for	 goodwill	 impairment	 tests	 We	 test	 goodwill	 for	 impairment	 annually,	 at	 the	 reporting	 unit	 level,	 and whenever	events	or	circumstances	make	it	more	likely	than	not	that	an	impairment	may	have	occurred,	such	as	a	significant adverse	change	in	the	business	climate	or	a	decision	to	sell	all	or	a	portion	of	a	reporting	unit.	We	perform	our	annual goodwill	impairment	test	as	of	October	1	and	monitor	for	interim	triggering	events	on	an	ongoing	basis.

We	review	goodwill	for	impairment	utilizing	either	a	qualitative	assessment	or	a	quantitative	goodwill	impairment	test.	If	we choose	to	perform	a	qualitative	assessment	and	determine	the	fair	value	more	likely	than	not	exceeds	the	carrying	value,	no further	evaluation	is	necessary.	For	reporting	units	where	we	perform	the	quantitative	goodwill	impairment	test,	we	compare the	fair	value	of	each	reporting	unit,	which	we	primarily	determine	using	an	income	approach	based	on	the	present	value	of discounted	cash	flows,	to	the	respective	carrying	value,	which	includes	goodwill.	If	the	fair	value	of	the	reporting	unit exceeds	its	carrying	value,	we	do	not	consider	the	goodwill	impaired.	If	the	carrying	value	is	higher	than	the	fair	value,	we recognize	the	difference	as	an	impairment	loss.

For	 reporting	 units	 where	 we	 perform	 a	 quantitative	 goodwill	 impairment	 test,	 the	 process	 requires	 valuation	 of	 the respective	reporting	unit,	which	we	primarily	determine	using	an	income	approach	based	on	a	discounted	five	year	forecasted cash	flow	with	a	year-five	residual	value.	We	compute	the	residual	value	using	the	constant	growth	method,	which	values	the forecasted	cash	flows	in	perpetuity.	The	assumptions	about	future	cash	flows	and	growth	rates	are	based	on	each	reporting unit's	long-term	forecast	and	are	subject	to	review	and	approval	by	senior	management.	A	reporting	unit's	discount	rate	is	a risk-adjusted	 weighted	 average	 cost	 of	 capital,	 which	 we	 believe	 approximates	 the	 rate	 from	 a	 market	 participant's perspective.	The	estimated	fair	value	could	be	impacted	by	changes	in	market	conditions,	interest	rates,	growth	rates,	tax rates,	 costs,	 pricing	 and	 capital	 expenditures.	 We	 categorize	 the	 fair	 value	 determination	 as	 Level	 3	 in	 the	 fair	 value hierarchy	due	to	its	use	of	internal	projections	and	unobservable	measurement	inputs.

We	completed	our	annual	assessment	of	goodwill	in	the	fourth	quarter	of	2023	and	determined	that	there	was	no	impairment	of goodwill.	Caterpillar's	market	capitalization	has	remained	significantly	above	the	net	book	value	of	the	Company.

An	unfavorable	change	in	our	expectations	for	the	financial	performance	of	our	reporting	units,	particularly	long-term	growth and	profitability,	would	reduce	the	fair	value	of	our	reporting	units.	The	demand	for	our	equipment	and	related	parts	is highly	cyclical	and	significantly	impacted	by	commodity	prices,	although	the	impact	may	vary	by	reporting	unit.	The	energy and	 mining	 industries	 are	 major	 users	 of	 our	 products,	 including	 the	 mineral	 extraction,	 oil	 and	 natural	 gas	 industries. Decisions	to	purchase	our	products	are	dependent	upon	the	performance	of	those	industries,	which	in	turn	are	dependent	in part	 on	 commodity	 prices.	 Lower	 commodity	 prices	 or	 industry	 specific	 circumstances	 that	 have	 a	 negative	 impact	 to	 the valuation	assumptions	may	reduce	the	fair	value	of	our	reporting	units.	Should	such	events	occur	and	it	becomes	more	likely than	 not	 that	 a	 reporting	 unit's	 fair	 value	 has	 fallen	 below	 its	 carrying	 value,	 we	 will	 perform	 an	 interim	 goodwill impairment	test(s),	in	addition	to	the	annual	impairment	test.		Future	impairment	tests	may	result	in	a	goodwill	impairment, depending	on	the	outcome	of	the	quantitative	impairment	test.	We	would	report	a	goodwill	impairment	as	a	non-cash	charge	to earnings.

Product	warranty	liability -	At	the	time	we	recognize	a	sale,	we	record	estimated	future	warranty	costs.		We	determine	the product	 warranty	 liability	 by	 applying	 historical	 claim	 rate	 experience	 to	 the	 current	 field	 population	 and	 dealer inventory.		Generally,	we	base	historical	claim	rates	on	actual	warranty	experience	for	each	product	by	machine	model/engine

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
Cat	 Financial	 provides	 guarantees	 to	 purchase	 certain	 loans	 of	 Caterpillar	 dealers	 from	 a	 special-purpose	 corporation (SPC)	that	qualifies	as	a	variable	interest	entity.		The	purpose	of	the	SPC	is	to	provide	short-term	working	capital	loans to	Caterpillar	dealers.		This	SPC	issues	commercial	paper	and	uses	the	proceeds	to	fund	its	loan	program.		Cat	Financial receives	a	fee	for	providing	this	guarantee.	Cat	Financial	is	the	primary	beneficiary	of	the	SPC	as	its	guarantees	result in	 Cat	 Financial	 having	 both	 the	 power	 to	 direct	 the	 activities	 that	 most	 significantly	 impact	 the	 SPC's	 economic performance	and	the	obligation	to	absorb	losses,	and	therefore	Cat	Financial	has	consolidated	the	financial	statements	of the	 SPC.	 	 As	 of	 December	 31,	 2023	 and	 2022,	 the	 SPC's	 assets	 of	 $1.35	 billion	 and	 $971	 million,	 respectively,	 were primarily	comprised	of	loans	to	dealers,	and	the	SPC's	liabilities	of	$1.35	billion	and	$970	million,	respectively,	were primarily	comprised	of	commercial	paper.		The	assets	of	the	SPC	are	not	available	to	pay	Cat	Financial's	creditors.	Cat Financial	may	be	obligated	to	perform	under	the	guarantee	if	the	SPC	experiences	losses.	No	loss	has	been	experienced	or is	anticipated	under	this	loan	purchase	agreement.

Cat	 Financial	 has	 commitments	 to	 extend	 credit	 to	 customers	 through	 lines	 of	 credit	 and	 other	 pre-approved	 credit arrangements.	Cat	Financial	applies	the	same	credit	policies	and	approval	process	for	these	commitments	as	we	do	for	other financing.	 Collateral	 is	 not	 required,	 but	 if	 credit	 is	 extended,	 collateral	 is	 generally	 required	 upon	 funding.	 The unused	commitments	to	extend	credit	to	customers	that	are	not	unconditionally	cancellable	was	$774	million	at	December	31, 2023.	Cat	Financial	also	has	pre-approved	lines	of	credit	and	other	credit	arrangements	with	Caterpillar	dealers;	however, we	generally	have	the	right	to	unconditionally	cancel,	alter,	or	amend	the	terms	at	any	time.

We	determine	our	product	warranty	liability	by	applying	historical	claim	rate	experience	to	the	current	field	population and	dealer	inventory.		Generally,	we	base	historical	claim	rates	on	actual	warranty	experience	for	each	product	by	machine model/engine	size	by	customer	or	dealer	location	(inside	or	outside	North	America).		We	develop	specific	rates	for	each product	shipment	month	and	update	them	monthly	based	on	actual	warranty	claim	experience.

The	 reconciliation	 of	 the	 change	 in	 our	 product	 warranty	 liability	 balances	 for	 the	 years	 ended	 December	 31,	 was	 as follows:

questions.question: What was the total change in fair value of CAT's Mortgage-Backed Debt Securities between December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, and how did this change compare to the change in unrealized losses on those securities over the same period?
questions.answer: The total fair value of CAT's Mortgage-Backed Debt Securities decreased from $327 million at December 31, 2022 to $320 million at December 31, 2023, a decrease of $7 million. Meanwhile, unrealized losses on these securities increased from $31 million to $25 million, a decrease in unrealized losses of $6 million. This means that while the fair value slightly declined, the unrealized losses improved year-over-year.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the total fair value ($327 million) and unrealized losses ($31 million) for Mortgage-Backed Debt Securities as of December 31, 2022.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the total fair value ($320 million) and unrealized losses ($25 million) for Mortgage-Backed Debt Securities as of December 31, 2023.
Step 3: Calculate the change in fair value: $327 million - $320 million = $7 million decrease.
Step 4: Calculate the change in unrealized losses: $31 million - $25 million = $6 million decrease in unrealized losses.
Step 5: Synthesize the findings to describe the total change in fair value and the corresponding change in unrealized losses.

questions.question: What was the total liability for postemployment benefits reported by CAT in 2023, and how did the pension benefits freeze impact the assumptions used in their financial reporting?
questions.answer: The total liability for postemployment benefits reported by CAT in 2023 was $621 million, which includes $56 million for other postemployment benefits and $565 million for non-qualified deferred compensation plans. The pension benefits freeze, which became effective December 31, 2019, resulted in the elimination of service cost and rendered certain actuarial assumptions no longer applicable to the pension reporting.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The 2023 liabilities for postemployment benefits were $56 million for other postemployment benefits and $565 million for non-qualified deferred compensation plans, totaling $621 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - As of December 31, 2019, all U.S. pension benefits were frozen, eliminating service cost and making certain assumptions no longer applicable.

Step 3: Synthesize - The total liability figure from 2023 can only be fully understood in the context of the pension freeze, which changed the nature of the assumptions used in financial reporting and eliminated ongoing service cost.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
All	U.S.	pension	benefits	are	frozen,	and	accordingly	there	is	no	longer	any	service	cost	and	certain	assumptions	are	no	longer	applicable. 1

The	 Liability	 for	 postemployment	 benefits	 reported	 in	 Statement	 3	 includes	 liabilities	 for	 other	 postemployment	 benefits	 and	 non-qualified deferred	 compensation	 plans.	 For	 2023,	 these	 liabilities	 were	 $56	 million	 and	 $565	 million,	 respectively.	 For	 2022,	 these	 liabilities	 were $58	million	and	$475	million,	respectively. 2

questions.question: What was the change in the total unrealized losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds' from December 31, 2022, to December 31, 2023, and how did this contribute to the overall change in unrealized losses across all government debt securities during that period?
questions.answer: The unrealized losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds' decreased from $5 million on December 31, 2022, to $3 million on December 31, 2023, resulting in a $2 million reduction. Across all government debt securities, the total unrealized losses decreased from $5 million (all attributed to Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds) to $3 million, meaning the entire change in unrealized losses for the category was driven by the reduction in losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds.'
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the total unrealized losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds' as of December 31, 2022: $5 million.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the total unrealized losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds' as of December 31, 2023: $3 million.
Step 3: Calculate the change in unrealized losses for 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds': $5 million - $3 million = $2 million reduction.
Step 4: From evidence_source_a, extract total unrealized losses across all government debt securities as of December 31, 2022: $5 million (entirely from 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds').

Step 5: From evidence_source_b, extract total unrealized losses across all government debt securities as of December 31, 2023: $3 million (also entirely from 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds').

Step 6: Conclude that the $2 million reduction in unrealized losses across all government debt securities was entirely attributable to the change in unrealized losses on 'Other U.S. and non-U.S. government bonds.'

Step 4: Synthesize - The acquisition led to additional intangible assets being recorded, which in turn increased amortization expenses, directly contributing to the rise in depreciation and amortization costs.

## COMPETITION

The Company's businesses operate in highly competitive markets. The Company competes based on product performance, quality, branding, service and/or price across the industries and markets served. A significant element of the Company's competitive strategy is to deliver solutions to our customers by manufacturing high-quality products at the best relevant global cost. Although no single company competes directly with Emerson in all of the Company's product lines, various companies compete in one or more product lines with the number of competitors varying by product line. Some competitors have substantially greater sales, assets and financial resources than Emerson and the Company also competes with many smaller companies. Management believes Emerson has a market leadership position in many of its product lines.

questions.question: What was the dollar value of the AspenTech acquisition in fiscal 2022, and how does this compare to the total balance of the AspenTech segment at the end of the prior fiscal year?
questions.answer: The AspenTech acquisition in fiscal 2022 had a dollar value of $7,289 million. This acquisition amount was significantly higher than the total balance of the AspenTech segment at the end of the prior fiscal year (September 30, 2021), which was $1,044 million. The acquisition therefore represented an increase of $6,245 million, or approximately 598%, compared to the previous year’s segment balance.

Step 3: Calculate the difference and percentage increase between the acquisition value and the prior year's segment balance to determine the relative scale of the acquisition.

questions.question: How did the Heritage AspenTech acquisition impact the structure and reported performance of Emerson's business segments in fiscal 2022, particularly with regard to the Automation Solutions segment's historical results?
questions.answer: The Heritage AspenTech acquisition led Emerson to identify a new segment in fiscal 2022, which combined the results of Heritage AspenTech and the Emerson Industrial Software Business. This new AspenTech segment caused a reclassification of prior year amounts in the Automation Solutions segment to conform to the new presentation. As a result, the Automation Solutions segment's historical results now exclude the Emerson Industrial Software Business, which is now part of the new AspenTech segment, thereby altering the reported performance of both segments.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, the Heritage AspenTech acquisition caused Emerson to identify a new segment in fiscal 2022 that combined the results of Heritage AspenTech and the Emerson Industrial Software Business.

Step 2: Also from evidence_source_a, the Automation Solutions segment's prior-year results were reclassified to align with the new segment structure, meaning the Emerson Industrial Software Business's results were no longer reported under Automation Solutions.

Step 3: From evidence_source_b, the AspenTech segment's increased backlog in fiscal 2022 was directly tied to the Heritage AspenTech acquisition, further indicating the acquisition had a material effect on segment-level reporting and performance metrics.

Step 4: Synthesize: The acquisition not only introduced a new segment but also required a retrospective reclassification of Automation Solutions' historical results, thereby altering the financial and operational narrative of that segment.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## (18) BUSINESS SEGMENTS INFORMATION

The Company designs and manufactures products and delivers services that bring technology and engineering together to provide innovative solutions for customers in a wide range of industrial, commercial and consumer markets around the world.

As a result of the Heritage AspenTech acquisition, the Company identified one additional segment in fiscal 2022. The new segment reflects the combined results of Heritage AspenTech and the Emerson Industrial Software Business (see Note 4 for further details). The results for this new segment include the historical results of the Emerson Industrial Software Business (which were previously reported in the Automation Solutions segment), while results related to the Heritage AspenTech business only include periods subsequent to the close of the transaction on May 16, 2022. Prior year amounts for the Automation Solutions segment have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.

The Company now reports four segments: Automation Solutions, AspenTech ; and Climate Technologies and Tools & Home Products , which together comprise the Commercial & Residential Solutions business.

The Automation Solutions segment enables process, hybrid and discrete manufacturers to maximize production, protect personnel and the environment, reduce project costs, and optimize their energy efficiency and operating costs through a broad offering of integrated solutions, software, services and products, including measurement and analytical instrumentation, industrial valves and equipment, and process control software and systems. Markets served include oil and gas, refining, chemicals, power generation, life sciences, food and beverage, automotive, pulp and paper, metals and mining, and municipal water supplies. The segment's major product offerings are described below.

- Measurement & Analytical Instrumentation products measure the physical properties of liquids or gases in a process stream and communicate this information to a process control system or other software applications, and analyze the chemical composition of process fluids and emissions to enhance quality and efficiency, as well as environmental compliance.
